Catalytic ozonation of NO x into HNO3 with low concentration ozone over MnO x -CeO2/TiO2: Two-phase synergistic effect of TiO2 Lina Guo a Fanyu Meng b Yiqing Zeng b Yong Jia a * Fuping Qian a Shule Zhang b * Qin Zhong b a Key Laboratory of Metallurgical Emission Reduction & Resources Recycling (Anhui University of Technology), Ministry of Education, Ma’anshan 243002, China Key Laboratory of Metallurgical Emission Reduction & Resources Recycling (Anhui University of Technology) Ministry of Education Ma’anshan 243002 China Key Laboratory of Metallurgical Emission Reduction & Resources Recycling (Anhui University of Technology), Ministry of Education, Ma’anshan 243002, China b School of Chemical Engineering, Nanjing University of Science and Technology, Nanjing 210094, China School of Chemical Engineering Nanjing University of Science and Technology Nanjing 210094 China School of Chemical Engineering, Nanjing University of Science and Technology, Nanjing 210094, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Anatase TiO2 (TiO2-A), TiO2-B, and TiO2-B/anatase mixed-phase TiO2 (TiO2-AB) are synthesized, and then utilized as supports for the preparation of Mn-Ce/TiO2-A, Mn-Ce/TiO2-B and Mn-Ce/TiO2-AB, respectively. These catalysts are investigated by various characterizations to understand different phase effect of TiO2 on physicochemical properties and catalytic activities for ozonation of NO x into HNO3, aiming to improve the total NO x removal efficiency during the subsequent wet absorption process. Characterizations reveal that the catalytic performances follow the order of Mn-Ce/TiO2-AB > Mn-Ce/TiO2-B > Mn-Ce/TiO2-A, which is relevant to the surface -OH content, oxygen vacancy amount, and reducibility property. The surface -OH groups participate in the transformation of O3 into reactive oxygen species (ROS), the oxygen vacancies increase the activity of surface -OH for ROS generation, and the superior reducibility property accelerates the cycling of Ce3+ → Ce4+ → Ce3+ reaction. Moreover, OH and HO2 radicals are identified as the main reactive species involved in the ozonation of NO x into HNO3. Especially, Mn-Ce/TiO2-AB presents the best catalytic performance mainly because of the optimal reducibility property. Keywords Crystal form Catalytic ozonation Nitrogen oxides Radical production 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxide (NO x ) are the main pollutant responsible for the generation of acid rain, photochemical smog as well as ozone (O3) depletion, and they can cause a variety of other harmful effects on the ecological environment [1,2]. Therefore, the reduction of NO x emission has attracted much concern in the field of air purification. Among the various NO x control technologies, selective catalytic reduction of NOx (SCR) with NH3 was flourished in power plant with a narrow temperature window (300–400 ℃) [3]. However, the SCR technology is unsatisfied for many small and medium-sized coal-fired boilers because the flue gas temperature is below 200 ℃ [4]. Therefore, it is urgent to explore innovative and effective denitrification technologies possessing a low operating temperature window. Alternatively, the method by combining O3 oxidation with wet flue gas desulfurization (WFGD) was proposed [5]. The insoluble NO (> 95 % of NO x ) is oxidized into NO2 with an O3/NO molar ratio < 1.0. After then, NO2 together with SO2 will be simultaneously removed during the subsequent wet absorption process [6]. Unfortunately, the NO2 absorption is difficult to be carried out in the limestone slurry during a typical WFGD process [7]. To further enhance the NO x removal efficiency, excess O3 is usually injected in favor of N2O5 formation to help the absorption process with an O3/NO molar ratio >1.0. This belongs to the deep oxidation of NO [8]. N2O5 is the most soluble species among all the nitrogen oxides. However, this method needs a large amount of O3, so the operating costs will increase. Catalytic ozonation reduces the O3 requirement in comparison to direct oxidation with O3 [9]. Therefore, from an economic standpoint, catalytic ozonation is more preferred than single ozonation. Prior work has reported the use of both homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts in water and air treatment fields. There are many homogeneous catalysts such as Fe(II), Ni(II), Zn(II), Mn(II) and Cr(III), which can improve the ozonation efficiency [10]. Nevertheless, the application of homogeneous catalysts has the following disadvantages: 1) Recovery of catalyst is costly; 2) An efficient catalyst and product separation is required through cleaning and purification steps, creating a great deal of wastewater which only can be discharged after treatment [11]. Heterogeneous catalysts can overcome the above drawbacks and simplify the product separation procedure. At present, significant successes have been gained in the heterogeneous catalysts owing to their wide applications in the catalysis field. Chemical reactions catalyzed by heterogeneous catalysts mainly consist of oxidation reactions [12], reduction reactions [13–17], simultaneous oxidation and reduction reactions [18], electrochemical reactions [19] and other organic transformation reactions [20–23]. In catalytic ozonation reactions, various heterogeneous catalysts have been successfully employed in ozonation of NO x with an O3/NO molar ratio > 1.0 [24–26]. According to the previous works, the conversion of NO x into N2O5 was significantly promoted over TiO2 or MnO x /Al2O3 catalyst [24,25]. Meanwhile, many catalytic ozonation systems with the production of hydroxyl radicals ( OH) have also been proposed by our group. For example, CuFe2O4 was applied to ozonation of NO x , demonstrating that the concentration of surface −OH was a key factor for OH production [26]. OH can oxidize NO2 into HNO3, and the two-order reaction rate is as high as 3.0 × 1010 mol/L·s [27]. Ding et al. utilized F doped Ce-Ti as ozonation catalyst, confirming that the activation of surface −OH was critical for the improvement of ozonation efficiency [28]. Despite this, the operating costs of these catalytic ozonation systems are still high due to a large amount of O3 consumption (O3/NO molar ratio > 1.0). So far, few literatures reported ozonation of NO x with low O3 concentrations. Thus there is a request to develop new catalytic ozonation systems using low O3 concentrations, which helps to reduce the operating costs for real application. It is known that the key factor for a practical application of catalytic ozonation is seeking for an effective catalyst. Thus finding a catalyst with a high activity and stability is necessary at O3/NO molar ratios < 1.0. Recently, our group found that catalysts with large amounts of oxygen vacancies effectively enhanced the oxidation of NO x even with low O3 concentrations [29], which was consistent with the findings reported by Liu et al. [30]. As has been reported, Mn-Ce composite oxides can offer a large quantity of oxygen vacancies as well as variable electronic structures, thus accelerating the creation of reactive oxygen species (ROS), finally presenting an outstanding catalytic activity in many oxidation reactions [31,32]. Generally, supported catalysts exhibit highly dispersed active components on the surface of supports that is conductive to catalytic behavior, so the choice of suitable supports is important for the Mn-Ce composite oxides. Anatase TiO2 (TiO2-A) is widely used in many fields such as photocatalysis, hydrogen sensors, support of catalysts and dye-sensitized solar cells, due to its high chemical stability, biological nontoxicity, low cost and excellent semiconducting properties [33,34]. TiO2-B was first synthesized by Marchand et al. in 1980 and was found in natural minerals by Banfield in 1991 [34]. It has been proved to be a promising material for use in photocatalysis, lithium ion batteries, humidity sensors and dye-sensitized solar cells [35]. TiO2-B/anatase mixed-phase composites (TiO2-AB) exhibit a better activity compared to the pure phase in some applications such as photocatalytic oxidation of iodide [36]. Nevertheless, the current investigation of TiO2 as a support is mainly focused on anatase. So, it is necessary to perform a comparative research about TiO2-A, TiO2-B, and TiO2-AB supporting Mn-Ce based catalysts. In the present work, TiO2-A, TiO2-B, and TiO2-AB are synthesized and then utilized as supports to prepare the series Mn-Ce/TiO2 samples for ozonation of NO x with an O3/NO molar ratio = 0.6 for the first time. These catalysts are characterized by various analytical methods. Based on the experimental data, a probable catalytic oxidation mechanism by O3 is proposed. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Synthesis of catalysts TiO2-A used in the present system was commercial anatase nano-TiO2. TiO2-B was prepared as follows. First, 1.2 g of commercial P25 was dispersed in 60 mL of aqueous solution (containing 10 M NaOH). Second, the suspensions were transformed to 100 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, and then maintained at 200 ℃ for 2 h in a microwave reactor. Third, the precipitate was filtered, then washed with 0.1 M HCl solution and distilled H2O until pH = 7. Finally, the powders were dried then calcined at 400 ℃ for 5 h in air. Additionally, the synthesis process of TiO2-AB was similar with that of TiO2-B, except that the reaction time was prolonged from 2 h to 3 h in the microwave reactor. In some cases, TiO2-A, TiO2-B and TiO2-AB were further simplified into Ti-A, Ti-B and Ti-AB, respectively. These MnO x -CeO2/TiO2 samples were prepared by an impregnation method. First, 0.10 g Mn(CH3COO)2·4H2O and 0.26 g Ce(NO3)3·6H2O were dissolved in deionized H2O to get a desirable concentration. After then, 0.16 g TiO2 was dispersed in the above solution with stirring for 120 min. Second, the mixture was placed in a water bath at 80 ℃. Finally, the coated TiO2 was dried at 120 ℃, then calcined at 400 ℃ for 4 h under air atmosphere. 2.2 Characterizations The crystalline phases of the prepared sample were recognized by X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) measurements (CuK α, Purkinje XD-3). The sample was measured for the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area using an Autosorb-iQ analyzer (Quantachrome Instruments, U.S.A.). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were carried out using a JEOL JEM-2100 F microscope equipped with an energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) detector. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was performed on a PHI-5000C ESCA system (Perkin Elmer) using an Mg Kα source (hm = 1253.6 eV). An inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometer (ICP-AES, Varian 720) was used for the analysis of metal contents in the catalyst. Oxygen vacancies were measured by Fluorescence Spectroscopy (PL) spectra using a Labran-HR800-type spectrophotometer (Jobin Yvon Co., France) with a He-Cd laser (λ =325 nm) as the light source. One spectrometer (Bruker EMX-10/12) was used to record the Electron Paramagnetic Resonance (EPR) signals of produced ∙OH and HO2∙ radicals using 5, 5- dimethyl -1-pyrroline-N-oxide (DMPO) as the trapping agent. Fourier transformation infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) spectra were collected on an IS10 spectrometer (Nicolet, USA). Programmed temperature reduction (H2-TPR) and temperature programmed desorption (H2O-TPD) experiments were carried out on an automated chemisorption analyzer (Quantachrome Instruments, U.S.A.). In a H2-TPR experiment, 0.10 g catalyst was first pretreated with He for 0.5 h, and then purged with H2/N2 gas mixture (10 % H2) for 40 min, finally the catalyst bed was heated at a rate of 10℃/min until the temperature achieved up to 700℃. Prior to a H2O-TPD experiment, 0.10 g catalyst was first pretreated with He for 1 h at 250℃ and then cooled to 50℃ followed by saturating with H2O using pulse model until saturation. After being purged with He for 30 min, the catalyst bed was heated to 500℃ at a rate of 10℃/min. The H2/H2O signals were detected by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). 2.3 Catalytic activity tests The experimental apparatus for ozonation of NO x (x = 1, 2) is shown in Fig. S1. NO, O3 and H2O vapor were simultaneously passed through the ozonation catalysts for catalytic reaction. The total flow consisting of O3 together with simulated flue gas was 220 mL min−1, and the O3 flow was 20 mL min−1. 0.20 g catalyst (20–40 mesh) was used in the reaction processes, corresponding to a space velocity of 30,000 h−1. The initial gas concentrations were as follows: NO = 400 ppm, O3/NO molar ratio = 0.6 and H2O = 6% (v/v). The conversion efficiency and NO2 selectivity during ozonation process could be calculated as: (1) η = C i n - C o u t C i n × 100 % (2) S = C o u t ( N O 2 ) C i n ( N O ) × 100 % Where η is the conversion efficiency, S is the NO2 selectivity. Cin and Cout are the inlet and outlet NO and NO x (x = 1, 2) contents, respectively. The inlet and outlet NO and NO2 concentrations were measured by in-situ FTIR gas analyzer (Sensonic IR-1). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic activity tests 3.1.1 Catalytic performance on ozonation of NOx (x = 1, 2) Fig. 1 presents comparative results of (a) NO, NO2 and NO x (x = 1, 2) concentration, (b) NO conversion efficiency, (c) NO2 selectivity and (d) NO x (x = 1, 2) conversion efficiency under different ozonation processes at 150 ℃ with an O3/NO molar ratio = 0.6 before WFGD; (e) total NO x (x = 1, 2) removal efficiency after WFGD. It can be observed that the NO concentration apparently decreases from 400 to 180 ppm, achieving 55 % of NO conversion efficiency in the O3 alone process. Moreover, the increment in NO2 concentration approximately equals to the decrement in NO concentration. In this case, the NO2 selectivity achieves up to 55 %. This is in good agreement with Lin’s report that O3 has a high selectivity to oxidize NO into NO2 [25]. When H2O is introduced into the O3 process, the NO content ascends by about 15 ppm, whereas the NO2 content descends by about 45 ppm simultaneously. This is because O3 can react with H2O to generate a small amount of •OH(4O3 + 2H2O = 4 •OH + 5O2), which can non-selectively oxidize NO and NO2 into HNO2 and HNO3 both at fast rate constants [26,37]. As a result, the amount of oxidants reacting with NO will be reduced, leading to an increase of NO concentration. In this O3 + H2O process, the NO conversion efficiency and NO2 selectivity descend to 51.3 % and 43.8 %, respectively. Meanwhile, the NO x (x = 1, 2) conversion efficiency ascends to 7.5 % due to the oxidation of NO x (x = 1, 2) into HNO2 and HNO3 by •OH radicals. Followed by the addition of Mn-Ce/TiO2-A, Mn-Ce/TiO2-B and Mn-Ce/TiO2-AB catalysts into this O3 + H2O process, it is noted that the NO content shows a weak decrease, whereas the corresponding NO2 concentration apparently declines by about 42, 50 and 73 ppm, respectively. Consequently, the NO conversion efficiency shows a slight increase to 55.2 %, 55.6 % and 57.1 %, whereas the NO2 selectivity presents an obvious decline to 33.2 %, 31.3 % and 25.5 % for Mn-Ce/TiO2-A, Mn-Ce/TiO2-B and Mn-Ce/TiO2-AB, respectively. The decrease of NO2 selectivity may be explained that these supported Mn-Ce based catalysts promote the generation of more •OH radicals in favor of NO2 into HNO3. However, it is worth mentioning that the only formation of •OH will result in an apparent decrease in NO conversion efficiency as compared to the O3 alone process with low O3 concentrations [29], which is inconsistent with the experimental results in the present system. Therefore, it is inferred that these supported Mn-Ce catalysts are also conductive to the generation of additional ROS, which can promote the NO conversion. As shown in Fig. S2, HNO3 is the sole liquid product, and the HNO2 content is almost negligible through chromatography analysis in the O3 + H2O + Mn-Ce/TiO2 system. The N element balancing calculation was shown in Table S1, which suggests that no other gas byproducts are formed during the catalytic ozonation process. From the above analysis, it is inferred that partial O3 oxidizes NO into NO2, and the rest O3 can be catalyzed by these supported Mn-Ce based catalysts to produce •OH and additional ROS, thus enhancing the NO x (x = 1, 2) conversion efficiency. According to the previous works, the formation of HO2 also occurs in the O3 + H2O process [38,39], and the reaction of NO + HO2 into HNO3 is fast [29]. Herein, a possible mechanism is put forward. That is, OH and HO2 radicals are the main ROS involved in the O3 + H2O + Mn-Ce/TiO2 system. •OH radicals can oxidize NO and NO2 both at fast rate constants, and the two-order reaction rates reacting with NO and NO2 reach up to 1.0 × 1010 and 3.0 × 1010 mol/L·s, respectively [27]. As contrast, HO2 can selectively oxidize NO because the reaction HO2 + NO is much faster than HO2 + NO2 [40]. This explanation is consistent with the experimental results in the present system. Due to the synergistic effects of OH and HO2 radicals, the NO x (x = 1, 2) conversion into HNO3 efficiency attains up to 21.5 %, 24.2 % and 30.6 % over Mn-Ce/TiO2-A, Mn-Ce/TiO2-B and Mn-Ce/TiO2-AB at 150 ℃, respectively. The Mn-Ce/TiO2-AB exhibits higher NO x (x = 1, 2) conversion efficiency than the black-TiO2 used in the previous document with low O3 concentrations [29]. WFGD is followed by the ozonation process, and 10 wt% NaOH solution is used as absorbent. As displayed in Fig. 1e, the NO x total removal efficiency achieves up to 77.1 % for the O3 + H2O + Mn-Ce/TiO2-AB method, compared with only 51.4 % for the O3 + H2O method after WFGD. Obviously, the introduction of catalyst promotes the conversion of NO x into HNO3 with much higher solubility, thereby significantly improving the subsequent absorption effect during the WFGD process. According to the emission standard of air pollutants for boiler (GB 13271−2014), the emission standard of NO x in China is 200 mg/m3. Therefore, the O3 + H2O + Mn-Ce/TiO2-AB oxidation method combined with WFGD can well meet the emission standard of NO x . 3.1.2 Effect of flue gas temperature Fig. 2 shows the variations of (a) NO conversion efficiency and (b) NO x (x = 1, 2) conversion into HNO3 efficiency with an O3/NO molar ratio = 0.6 under different temperatures of flue gas. It is noted that the NO and NO x (x = 1, 2) conversion efficiency is nearly unchanged within the temperature range of 120–180 ℃. Therefore, these supported Mn-Ce based catalysts can be well used for ozonation of NO x at a temperature below 180 ℃. This temperature can meet the demand of most of the small and medium-sized coal-fired boilers. 3.1.3 Stability and durability The stability of Mn-Ce/TiO2-AB was tested, as displayed in Fig. 3 a. No obvious deactivation is observed during the 60 h test at 150 ℃, so it is inferred that Mn-Ce/TiO2-AB has a good stability. After the stability test, this Mn-Ce/TiO2-AB catalyst was reused to measure its sulfur resistance through a long exposure to SO2 for another 48 h. As presented in Fig. 3b, when 500 ppm SO2 is added into the O3 + H2O + reused Mn-Ce/TiO2-AB process, the NO concentration instantly rises by about 15 ppm, whereas the corresponding NO2 concentration is significantly reduced by about 50 ppm within 20 min. After then, the NO and NO2 concentrations remain relatively stable till 48 h. This phenomenon may be explained from the following two aspects. On one hand, SO2 can compete with NO x for •OH radicals [41], which results in an increase of NO and NO2 concentration. On the other hand, SO2 can act as a promoter to decrease the NO2 concentration via a synergistic absorption effect between SO2 and NO2 [42]. In addition, after the withdrawal of SO2, the NO and NO2 concentrations will recover to the original level within 20 min. These observations indicate that the reused Mn-Ce/TiO2-AB catalyst shows a better performance in regarding SO2 poisoning. The XRD patterns of Mn-Ce/TiO2-AB before and after reuse for the sulfur resistance test are shown in Fig. 3c. The XRD characteristic peak of Mn-Ce/TiO2-AB does not change its position and no other new peaks appear after the sulfur resistance test. It implies that this reused Mn-Ce/TiO2-AB catalyst still possesses a stable structure under SO2 atmosphere. 3.1.4 Determination of residue ozone The residual O3 was measured and the results are shown in Fig. 4 . The residue O3 concentration is below 2 ppb in the tail gas during O3 + H2O or O3 + H2O + Mn-Ce/TiO2-AB processes. It indicates that O3 is almost completely consumed during the ozonation process with low O3 concentrations, which is in good agreement with Lin’s report [25]. 3.2 Structural characterization The crystal form of TiO2 and those supported Mn-Ce based catalysts are determined by XRD, as presented in Fig. 5 . TiO2-A shows the peaks at 2θ = 25.3, 37.9, 48.1, 54.3 and 63.0° corresponding to anatase phase (PDF#71−1169) [43]. TiO2-B presents the characteristic peaks at 14.2, 25.1, 28.7, 43.9, 48.6°, and so on, which are indexed to monoclinic structure [44]. TiO2-AB displays its diffraction peaks typically at 14.2, 25.3, 37.9, 43.9, 48.6°, which are assigned to the mixed TiO2-B/anatase mixed-phase. These observations reveal that different crystal forms of TiO2 supports have been successfully prepared. The supported Mn-Ce based catalyst is similar to the corresponding support, and no diffraction peaks attributed to Mn-Ce oxide can be detected. In addition, the peak intensity of these supported Mn-Ce based catalyst is relatively weaker as compared to the corresponding TiO2 support. It suggests the highly dispersed Mn-Ce species on the different crystal forms of TiO2 supports [45,46], which is in good agreement with the TEM analysis. The BET specific surface area is 87.3, 105.2 and 110.9 m2 g−1 for TiO2-A, TiO2-B and TiO2-AB, respectively. When Mn-Ce species is loaded onto their surface, it is decreased to 59.6, 93.5 and 85.2 m2 g−1, respectively. This result indicates that different crystal forms of TiO2 supports lead to the different BET surface areas. With respect to the ozonation activity (Fig. 1), it has no positive correlation with the BET surface area, indicating a weak effect of surface area on ozonation activity. The morphologies of these supported Mn-Ce based catalysts were examined by TEM (Fig. 6 ). The TEM images of Mn-Ce/TiO2-A in Fig. 6a and b show that TiO2-A has a nanopolyhedron morphology with an average size of 30 nm, and the ultra-small Mn-Ce nanoparticles are well dispersed on its surface. It can be clearly observed from Fig. 6c and d that TiO2-B has a fibrous morphology with a diameter of 50−100 nm. And the well-dispersed Mn-Ce nanoparticles loaded on TiO2-B mainly fall in a range of 6−14 nm. As presented in Fig. 6e and f, TiO2-AB exhibits almost the same morphology as TiO2-B except that the diameter of the nanorod increases and some short rod-like particles appear. Moreover, the Mn-Ce nanoparticles show a uniform deposition on TiO2-AB and the sizes of nanoparticles are mainly between 10 and 20 nm. The concomitant presence of O, Ti, Mn and Ce elements in the Mn-Ce/TiO2-AB catalyst is affirmed by EDS spectrometry and the relevant mapping (Fig. 7 a and b, respectively). The EDS elemental mapping clearly shows that each element is homogeneously dispersed throughout the Mn-Ce/TiO2-AB nanocomposite. 3.3 Surface state and redox properties 3.3.1 XPS analysis The oxidation states and surface chemical composition was analyzed by XPS method. As displayed in Fig. S3, the binding energies of Ti 2p1/2 (458.5 eV) and Ti 2p3/2 (464.4 eV) correspond to Ti4+ species [4]. Two bands attributed to Mn 2p1/2 and Mn 2p3/2 are shown in Fig. 8 a. According to the literature, the Mn 2p3/2 spectrum is deconvoluted into three obvious peaks corresponding to Mn3+, Mn4+ and a satellite [47]. As observed from the Ce 3d XPS spectra (Fig. 8b), the bands marked u′ and v′ represent Ce3+ species. And the bands u, u″, u‴, v, v″, and v‴ are ascribed to Ce4+ species [48]. XPS elementary and cation surface concentration of the prepared catalysts are summarized in Table 1 . Notably, the surface Mn4+/(Mn3+ + Mn4+) and Ce3+/(Ce3+ + Ce4+) ratios of Mn-Ce/TiO2-AB are higher than those of the other two catalysts. Thus, loading of Mn-Ce species onto TiO2-AB support greatly promotes the redox balance (Mn3+ + Ce4+ ↔Mn4+ + Ce3+) shifting to right. The Mn, Ce and Ti contents in these supported Mn-Ce based catalysts were determined by ICP-AES analysis. As revealed by the compositional data listed in Table 1, the loading amounts of Mn and Ce onto TiO2-A, TiO2-B and TiO2-AB supports are very close to each other. Fig. 8c displays that the O1 s XPS spectra are composed of three peaks after fitting, which are attributed to O in lattice (529.7–529.9 eV, labeled as Oβ), O in hydroxyl (−OH) groups (530.5–531.5 eV, designated as Oα) and adsorbed molecular H2O (above 532.5 eV, named as Oγ) [49,50]. The relative atomic ratio of surface −OH is calculated based on the relative area of those sub-peaks. As shown in Table 1, it decreases in the order of Mn-Ce/TiO2-AB (43.2 %) ≈ Mn-Ce/TiO2-B (43.1 %) > Mn-Ce/TiO2-A (29.9 %). 3.3.2 PL analysis PL emission spectra were utilized for investigating surface defects, as presented in Fig. 9 . Clearly, these supported Mn-Ce based catalysts show a broad band, probably the convolution of two peaks. Peak 1 at 440 nm represents self-trapped excitons, and peak 2 at 480 nm is assigned to oxygen vacancies [4]. Oxygen vacancies inhibit the combination of electron and hole, thus lowering the PL intensity [51]. Thus, a larger amount of oxygen vacancies can be evidenced by a lower PL intensity. According to the PL intensities of different catalysts, the decreasing order of oxygen vacancy concentration is Mn-Ce/TiO2-AB ≈ Mn-Ce/TiO2-B > Mn-Ce/TiO2-A. 3.3.3 H2-TPR analysis H2-TPR was carried out for identifying the reducibility property of these samples. Fig. 10 displays that all the supported Mn-Ce based catalysts show a broad peak in the scope of 200–650 ℃, which belongs to the stepwise reduction of MnO x , overlapped with the reduction of surface Ce4+ [52]. In comparison to the other two samples, an apparent shift towards lower temperatures is observed for Mn-Ce/TiO2-AB, indicating an increased reducibility of Ce and Mn ions. 3.4 Discussion on catalytic ozonation mechanism 3.4.1 Direct evidence of OH and HO2 radicals by EPR The EPR DMPO spin-trapping technique was used for examining the creation of OH and HO2 radical. This test was carried out by putting 0.1 g Mn-Ce/TiO2-AB in 10 mL ultrapure water (containing 100 mM DMPO) with continuous O3 aeration for 5 min at room temperature. Fig. 11 shows that the system generates a quartet EPR signal of DMPO- •OH adduct, confirming the presence of •OH radical [53]. The determination of HO2 radical is performed in methanol instead of ultrapure water, and the peak characteristics of HO2 radical can also be observed [54]. From the above results, it is deduced that Mn-Ce/TiO2-AB results in the generation of OH and HO2 radicals, which have stronger oxidation ability than O3. Therefore, it is concluded that OH and HO2 radicals realize the catalytic ozonation of NO x . 3.4.2 Use of insitu-FTIR to probe the role of catalytic active sites The infrared characterizations were utilized to probe the interaction between O3 and the catalyst surface. These supported Mn-Ce based catalysts were blended with H2O and dried at 120 ℃ overnight, then the corresponding IR spectra were immediately collected, as displayed in Fig. 12 . Clearly, the stretching and bending vibrations of surface −OH groups at 3500 cm−1 are intensified after H2O treatment, revealing that H2O can be easily adsorbed on the catalyst surface for the formation of surface −OH groups. The increase is more apparent for Mn-Ce/TiO2-AB and Mn-Ce/TiO2-B, which is most probably due to a large amount of oxygen vacancies on their surface. Oxygen vacancies favor the adsorption of water molecules in the surface layer [55]. To further explore the H2O adsorption property, H2O-TPD test was carried out. As presented in Fig. 12d, these profiles can be divided into four broad peaks, which are ascribed to the desorbed H2O species with different thermal stability. Clearly, these desorption peaks of Mn-Ce/TiO2-AB shift to high temperatures as compared to the other two samples, suggesting an increase of H2O adsorption strengths for Mn-Ce/TiO2-AB. Additionally, the H2O adsorption capacity can be calculated based on the integral area of these desorption peaks. As a result, Mn-Ce/TiO2-AB has the optimal H2O adsorption capacity among these catalysts. The order of H2O adsorption capacity is as follows: Mn-Ce/TiO2-AB > Mn-Ce/TiO2-B > Mn-Ce/TiO2-A, which is well consistent with the IR results. After then, O3 was introduced into the in-situ pool, and the IR spectra were collected with testing time. It is found that the band at 3500 cm−1 is apparently weakened with the testing time increasing, suggesting that the surface −OH groups act as active sites participating in the catalytic reaction constantly. In addition, the decrease is more significant for Mn-Ce/TiO2-AB within 5 min test, revealing the reaction of surface −OH groups with O3 into ROS is significantly accelerated. Clearly, the ROS generation rate follows the decreasing order of Mn-Ce/TiO2-AB > Mn-Ce/TiO2-B > Mn-Ce/TiO2-A, coinciding with the order of ozonation activity (Fig. 1). The surface −OH properties, including surface −OH concentration and activation may play an important part in ROS creation [28]. Note that this order of ROS generation rate is inconsistent with that of surface −OH concentration (Fig. 8c). Therefore, the concentration of surface −OH groups is not the sole factor influencing the catalytic ozonation. The activation of surface −OH is closely related to the concentration of oxygen vacancies. There are two kinds of surface −OH groups, including −OH connected to metal ions and −OH linked to oxygen vacancies. In comparison to the former, the latter can promote the adsorption and decomposition of O3, thereby presenting a high activation to accelerate the ROS generation [28]. As shown in Fig. 9, Mn-Ce/TiO2-AB has the similar concentration of surface oxygen vacancies with that of Mn-Ce/TiO2-B, but the former seems to be more favorable for the ROS generation, indicating that the concentration of oxygen vacancies is not the main reason for the catalytic activities either. 3.4.3 Investigating the role of electron transfer couple by XPS analysis Fig. 13 presents the XPS spectra of Mn-Ce/TiO2-AB before and after ozonation. It is observed from Fig. 13a that the relative content of surface Ce4+ increases from 68.1% to 74.5%, while that of Ce3+ decreases from 31.9% to 25.5% after ozonation, suggesting that Ce3+ is easily oxidized to Ce4+ by O3. It indicates that Ce serves as the active sites to transfer electrons, following the sequence of Ce3+ → Ce4+ → Ce3+. Simultaneously, the binding energies of Ce 3d shift to the higher ones after ozonation, which is mainly caused by the decrease of electron density around Ce atoms. As seen from Fig. 13b, the relative content of Oβ/(Oα + Oβ + Oγ) is almost invariable after ozonation. As is well known, O3 reacts with the surface −OH groups into ROS with the participation of H2O, that is, both Oα and Oγ take part in the ozonation process. Therefore, it is speculated that the utilization of Oβ also takes place, resulting in the reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+ [56]. However, there are no changes in the XPS spectra of Ti 2p and Mn 2p for Mn-Ce/TiO2-AB before and after ozonation, as shown in Fig. S4. From the above analysis, Ce3+ is easily oxidized to Ce4+ by O3, while the lattice oxygen acts as a reducing agent to reduce Ce4+ to Ce3+ simultaneously during the ozonation process. Therefore, the reducibility of Ce ions may become the dominant factor determining the difference of catalytic activities between Mn-Ce/TiO2-AB and Mn-Ce/TiO2-B. According to the H2-TPR results (Fig. 10), the reducibility of Ce ions is apparently enhanced for Mn-Ce/TiO2-AB. It implies that the reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+ is promoted to accomplish the cycling of Ce3+ → Ce4+ → Ce3+ reaction. Accordingly, the ROS generation rate will be accelerated, as shown in Fig. 12. As a result, although Mn-Ce/TiO2-AB has a similar concentration of surface −OH groups and oxygen vacancies with Mn-Ce/TiO2-B, the former is more effective for the ozonation of NO x than the latter. On account of the above observations and reviews of the literature [[56,57],58], the schemetic representation of catalytic ozonation mechanism is shown in Fig. 14 . Based on this mechanism, the following reaction steps would occur. First, H2O molecules tend to be strongly adsorbed and activated on the catalyst surface, forming surface −OH groups (Step 1). Meanwhile, O3 should interact with the surface −OH groups by electrostatic forces and hydrogen bonding, promoting the electron transfer (Step 2). After then, the H–O and OO bonds are weakened, and then the decomposition of intermediates leads to the generation of OH and HO2 radicals (Step 3). Such radicals have greater oxidizing efficiency than O3, which can oxidize the gaseous and adsorbed NO x to HNO3 (Step 4). To keep the electrostatic balance, Ce4+ is reduced to Ce3+ by the lattice oxygen (Step 5). Finally, a cycling reaction in the sequence of Ce3+ →Ce4+→ Ce3+ is accomplished (Step 6). 4 Conclusions A comparative study of Mn-Ce/TiO2-A, Mn-Ce/TiO2-B and Mn-Ce/TiO2-AB is conducted to understand different phase effect of TiO2 on the ozonation activity of NO x (x = 1, 2). The NO x conversion into HNO3 efficiency follows the order of Mn-Ce/TiO2-A < Mn-Ce/TiO2-B < Mn-Ce/TiO2-AB. The surface −OH groups and lattice oxygen participate in the catalytic ozonation process, and Ce serves as the active site to transfer electrons. Among these catalysts, Mn-Ce/TiO2-AB presents the best catalytic activity mainly because of the optimal reducibility property. OH and HO2 radicals are the main reactive oxygen species contributed to the enhancement of ozonation activity. •OH has non-selectivity oxidizing NO and NO2 both at fast rate constants, while HO2 can selectively react to NO also fast. After WFGD, the NO x removal efficiency achieves up to 77.1 % for the O3 + H2O + Mn-Ce/TiO2-AB method, which can well meet the emission standard of NO x in China (< 200 mg/m3). coredata.dc:description: Anatase TiO2 (TiO2-A), TiO2-B, and TiO2-B/anatase mixed-phase TiO2 (TiO2-AB) are synthesized, and then utilized as supports for the preparation of Mn-Ce/TiO2-A, Mn-Ce/TiO2-B and Mn-Ce/TiO2-AB, respectively. These catalysts are investigated by various characterizations to understand different phase effect of TiO2 on physicochemical properties and catalytic activities for ozonation of NO x into HNO3, aiming to improve the total NO x removal efficiency during the subsequent wet absorption process. Characterizations reveal that the catalytic performances follow the order of Mn-Ce/TiO2-AB > Mn-Ce/TiO2-B > Mn-Ce/TiO2-A, which is relevant to the surface -OH content, oxygen vacancy amount, and reducibility property. The surface -OH groups participate in the transformation of O3 into reactive oxygen species (ROS), the oxygen vacancies increase the activity of surface -OH for ROS generation, and the superior reducibility property accelerates the cycling of Ce3+ → Ce4+ → Ce3+ reaction. Moreover, OH and HO2 radicals are identified as the main reactive species involved in the ozonation of NO x into HNO3. Especially, Mn-Ce/TiO2-AB presents the best catalytic performance mainly because of the optimal reducibility property.
coredata.dc:title: Catalytic ozonation of NO x into HNO3 with low concentration ozone over MnO x -CeO2/TiO2: Two-phase synergistic effect of TiO2
